div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexand``ria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
S.S Osmanieh, Wednesday 4 p.m. Sept 18, October 2. 16, and 30
S.S. Ismallia, Wednesday 4 p.m. Sept. 11, 25, October 9 and 23

The fast steamers Assouan, Minieh, and Menzaieh leave Alexandria alternately on Satrudays at 4 p.m. for Jarra (for Jersalem), Caifla (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Demasceous) an alternative weeks to Rhodes, Smyra, Mitylone, Dardanelles, Callipoli and Constantinople.
The mail steamers Dakahileh and Kosseir leave Suez Alternativly on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the sudan sercice to Khartoum.
Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai Yambo and Keddah, continuing in alternative weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Adau.
For further information refer to the Co.'s Agencies at ALexandria, Cario, Port Said, Suex, or to THOS. COOX & Sox (Egypt) Ltd, HAMBURG AMERICA RKISE BURAU OR OTHER Tourist Agencies.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular Service fortnightly from HAMBURG; weekly from ANTWERP; every 4 weeks from, ALEXANDRIA for ROTTERDAM and HAMBURG. Goods forwarded at through-rates from all German Railway Station on direct Bills of Landing to ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO, SYRIA, etc. Special facilities for conveyances of cotton, etc from Alexandria via Rotterdam and Hamburg to German manufacturing towns.
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA:
October 13th S.S. "Delos from Antwerp and will sail for Rotterdam and Hamburg
October 13th S.S. "Chios" from Hamburg
October 13th S.S. "Samos" from Hamburg.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l’étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d’effets sur l’Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 3 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-904

Arrical at Triente on Wednesday about 11 a.m. A Train de Lure leave the same evenng, 6:35 p.m. for Vienna, Frankfort, Cologne, Brussel, Oatende and London. Arrival at London on Friday 5:18 p.m.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: A Sleeping Car is Attatched every night to the 11.30 p.m. train from Cario and Alexandria and vice versa supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: A Sleeping and Resturant car is attatched to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo to Luxor every Monday, Wednesday, and Saturday returning form Luxor every Tuesday, THursdya and SUndat at 5.30 p.m. Fare Cairo, Luxor including Sleeper P.T. 201.
A Resturant Car is attatced to the 10.30 a.m. train from Luxor to Assouau every Tuesday, Thursday & SUnday, thorughout the Summer returning form Assouan every Monday, Wednesday, and Saturday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

p.hi: Public Analyst for the City of Glasgow and the Counties of Lanark, Renfrew, &c.

div.head: Notices to Advertiser
div.p: The "Egyptian Gazette" has given no advertising agency or company in Egypt any monopoly or exclusive right to act as advertising Agents on its behalf. Advertisements of every description are recieved at the offices of the "Gazette" from advertisers direct.

div.head: Cheap Prepaid Advertisements
div.p: Under this heading advertisements are inserted at the following rates :—
The address is counted. The advertisement must appear on consecutive days for above rates to be obtained. 50% extra is charged for advertisements not appearing consecutively.

All such advertisements must be prepaid, and to this rule no exception whatever will be made. Letters in reply to advertisements will be posted to any address if a few stamps are sent by the advertiser to cover postage.

Later in the season, Smoked Fish will also be obtainable at the above stores.

Drawing, Painging, Music, Dancing, Needlework, Book-keeping and Shorthand. Boarders and day boarders received. Private lessons given. Autumn term commences Monday Sept 30th. div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
Cairo Offices: - Telegraph Building Boulac Road ( opposite All Saints Church). P.O.B No. 8. Telephone No. 878.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
THURSDAY, October 3, 1905.

div.head: FRIENDSHIP WITH TURKEY
div.p: Those British politicians who promised great things of the Peace Congress at The Hauge can scarcely have forseen one of the advantages which this apparently futile meeting is said to have brought to their country. This advantage, a direct consquence of the Congress, is the greater friendship with Turkey. Those who think to understand the Balkan question by reading blue books will no doubt deplore any improvement of diplomatic relations, and the improvement of British commerce with Turkey is scarcely likely to sugar their pill. Bit is is worth wile noting that serveral French authorities on the Macedonian question have stated that the English enthusassts could never hace their reforms carried out unless the British Ambassador were able to go before the Sultan armed with a strong friendship and an unchallenged prestige. Unfortunatly it cannot be said that British prestige at Constantinople has been unchallenged of late.

An indefastigable and subtle diplomatist, Baron Marshall von Beiberstein has contriebed that German should receive many sugar plums in the way of orders for guns, railway concessions, and what not, and British traders have itched at seeing their profits stationary or declining. However, if we are to believe a writer in the "Siecle," it is Great Britain now that leads the dance. Before leacing Constantinople for The Hague, Baron Marshall con Biberstein mitted to see to it that a great hurt to Turkish pride - her inclusion among the secondary Powers convoked to the congress - was removed. This, coming after a deception by Germany - withdrawing her support in the Tabah affair when things became serious - sufficed to change the Sultan's attitude. Admiral Sir Charles Drury and the officers of the Mediterranean Fleet were recently received by the Sultan in a way which slearly signalised the change. All precedents in the matter of etiquette were set aside, and the party were recievved with the ceremonial heretofore reserved to the Princes of the Blood; and in spite of the activity of the German Charge d'Affaires, a much better time for British merchants and financiers is promised.

div.head: THE SUEZ ROUTE
div.p: "At a time when public attention in the United States has been recalled to the transfer of the Altantic Fleet to the Pacific by Mr. Hearst once more raising the cry of "the danger from Japan," a very interesting suggestion has been made by an American admiral, whose words will carry wright," says the "evening Standard," Rear - Admiral Clark is the captian of the famous battleship 'oregon," which steamed from the Paficif coast to Cubam via the Straigts of Magellan, at the outset of the war with SPain. He is storngly in fabour of sending the Atlantic Fleet to the Pacific by way of the Seuz Canal, owing to the dangers attending the passage of the Magellan Straits, the lack of good anchorage, and the tortuous run of 200 miles between Sandy Point and Port Famine, where vessels might encounter serious danger when proceeding in squadron formation.' The admiral's objectins are backed up by statisticains, who proe that if the fleet proceeds via Suex to the Philippines it will have 4364 fewer miles to cover, will consequentely take fory days over the voyage, as against fifty-six, and will save E80,000 over its coal."

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

The Italian Army.
div.p: Detatchments of ITalian troops coming from Massawa thrugh the Suex Canal the day before yesterday aboard the S.S. "Enna"

div.head: Egyptian Falence
div.p: The Egyptian origin of Oriental faience is defended in an interesting article in the October number of the "Burlington Magazine" by Dr. A. T. Butler.

div.head: The Eebehieh Quarter
div.p: The Italian Vice-Consul at Cairo made a raid on Tuesday in a number of houses in the Eshekieth qyarter. Three ruffians were arrested and will be brought before the Italian Consulate.

div.head: The "Comptior Financier"
div.p: In order to extend the business of the comercial branch of the Comptior Financier et Commerciel d'Egypte it has been decided to appoint Mr. Henry Seffer to the management, who together with Mr. Sidney Wikinson will control this portion of the company's business.
